Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Electrocorticographic Monitoring in Severe Traumatic Brain Injury

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised 1:1 to either standard care or a tiered intervention protocol

Participants.evidence: Conducted in an intensive care setting, this randomised controlled trial included patients undergoing surgery for severe TBI with subdural electrode placement.

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to either standard care or a tiered intervention protocol aimed at SD suppression.

Objective.evidence: This study assesses the feasibility and efficacy of a treatment protocol guided by electrocorticographic monitoring of SDs.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in secondary injury over a 10-day period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention group and 100 to the control group, recruited between January 2020 and June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, following an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group demonstrated a significant reduction in secondary injury (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events occurred in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with no severe complications reported.
